html:
Etymology 1[edit]

From Proto-Italic *razdō, from Proto-Indo-European *rh₁d-dʰ-, extended from *reh₁d- (“to scrape, scratch, gnaw”). See rōdō. Cognate with Proto-Celtic *rasdeti (“to scrape; to scratch”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈraː.doː/, [ˈraː.d̪oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈra.do/, [ˈraː.d̪ɔ]

Verb[edit]

rādō (present infinitive rādere, perfect active rāsī, supine rāsum); third conjugation

  1. I scrape, shave, scratch.
  2. I rub, smooth.
  3. I touch (upon), brush along, graze.

Descendants[edit]
  • Aromanian: arad, aradiri
  • Catalan: raure
  • Friulian: radâ
  • Galician: raer
  • → German: radieren
  • Italian: radere
  • Old French: rere
  • Portuguese: raer, rer
  • Romanian: rade, radere
  • Spanish: raer

(through Vulgar Latin frequentative *rāsō):

  • Catalan: rasar
  • French: raser
  • Friulian: rasâ
  • Galician: rasar
  • Italian: rasare
  • Occitan: rasar
  • Portuguese: rasar
  • Sardinian: rasai, arrasai, rasare
  • Venetian: raxar

(through Vulgar Latin *rāsicō):

  • Catalan: rascar
  • Galician: rascar
  • Portuguese: rascar
  • Spanish: rascar

Etymology 2[edit]

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈra.doː/, [ˈra.d̪oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈra.do/, [ˈraː.d̪ɔ]

Noun[edit]

radō

  1. dative singular of radon
  2. ablative singular of radon

References[edit]

  • rado in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • rado in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • rado in Charles du Fresne du Cange’s Glossarium Mediæ et Infimæ Latinitatis (augmented edition, 1883–1887)
  • rado in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
  • Pokorny, Julius (1959) Indogermanisches etymologisches Wörterbuch [Indo-European Etymological Dictionary] (in German), volume III, Bern, München: Francke Verlag, page 854
